case_vignette:
A 73-year-old man comes in to the emergency department because of nausea and severe pain in his upper abdomen and right shoulder blade for the past day. He was able to eat a little for breakfast but vomited up the meal a couple of hours later. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years and drinks 4 beers every week. He appears acutely distressed. His temperature is 38.8°C (102°F), pulse is 124/min, and blood pressure is 92/68 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 95%. The abdomen is soft and there is tenderness to palpation of the right upper quadrant with soft crepitus. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 14.3 g/dL
Leukocyte count 18,100/mm3
Platelet count 216,000/mm3
Serum
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, SGOT) 41 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, SGPT) 19 U/L
Alkaline phosphatase 110 U/L
Total bilirubin 0.9 mg/dL
Direct bilirubin 0.2 mg/dL
Albumin 4.1 g/dL
Ultrasonography of the right upper quadrant shows a gallbladder with an air-filled, thickened wall and no stones in the lumen.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?"

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Gastrointestinal System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been feeling nauseous and have severe pain in my upper belly and right shoulder blade since yesterday.
Have you experienced any vomiting or loss of appetite along with the pain?
Yes, I vomited after trying to eat a little for breakfast this morning.

Have you noticed any bloating or burping?

**Final Diagnosis:** Gallstones.

trial_1.summarized_conversation: A patient arrives at the emergency room with complaints of severe upper belly pain and right shoulder blade pain, accompanied by nausea and vomiting. The symptoms began yesterday, shortly after the patient ate breakfast. The patient denies any other medical conditions or medication use. There is no family history of similar symptoms.
trial_1.vignette_mcq: Emphysematous cholecystitis. The patient's symptoms, tenderness to palpation of the right upper quadrant with soft crepitus, and ultrasonography findings of an air-filled, thickened gallbladder wall are consistent with this diagnosis.
trial_1.vignette_frq: The most likely diagnosis is acute cholecystitis with gallstone obstruction and superimposed cholangitis.
trial_1.multiturn_mcq: Final Diagnosis: Chronic pancreatitis with pseudocyst rupture.
trial_1.singleturn_mcq: Final Diagnosis: Emphysematous cholecystitis. (This diagnosis is based on the patient's symptoms of severe pain in the upper belly and right shoulder blade, along with nausea, which are common symptoms of emphysematous cholecystitis. This condition is characterized by gas in the gallbladder wall, which can cause these symptoms. Other possibilities, such as primary sclerosing cholangitis, chronic pancreatitis with pseudocyst rupture, and perforated duodenal ulcer, may present with different symptoms or additional symptoms, making them less likely based on the information provided.)
trial_1.summarized_mcq:
The most likely diagnosis is: Emphysematous cholecystitis.

Symptoms of emphysematous cholecystitis include severe upper abdominal pain, right shoulder pain, nausea, and vomiting. This condition occurs when there is gas in the gallbladder wall or the tissue surrounding it, often due to a bacterial infection. It is a medical emergency that requires prompt surgical intervention.

Primary sclerosing cholangitis, chronic pancreatitis with pseudocyst rupture, and perforated duodenal ulcer may also cause similar symptoms, but their presentations differ in certain aspects. Primary sclerosing cholangitis is characterized by progressive obstructive jaundice, while chronic pancreatitis with pseudocyst rupture typically presents with severe abdominal pain and peritoneal signs. Perforated duodenal ulcer usually causes sudden, severe abdominal pain, often with peritoneal signs and guarding.
